title: How to Maintain a Clothes Dryer

steps.headline: Clean out your lint filter every time you use the dryer.
steps.description: Really, every time. Lint is the fuzzy stuff that sticks to the screen. Scrape it off, and toss it in the trash. If you let the lint build up, it not only will make your clothes dry slower and increase your electricity bill, but it’s also a fire hazard.

steps.headline: Wash the lint screen every three months.
steps.description: Though you’re cleaning off the lint every time you do a load, you do sometimes need to perform a more thorough cleaning. You can pop the lint filter in the top rack of the dishwasher, or wash it in the sink with some soap or laundry detergent. Let the filter air dry on a towel before you put it back in the dryer. This is especially important to do if you use dryer sheets, because they can leave residue.

steps.headline: Unplug the dryer and vacuum out the lint trap once a year.
steps.description: The lint trap is the space where the screen usually goes. First clean it with a lint brush, and then with the small, flat vacuum hose attachment. Depending on how much lint is in there, you might have to run the hose many times. If you don’t have a lint brush, skip straight to vacuuming.

steps.headline: Clean the inside and outside of the dyer with a damp rag about once a month.
steps.description: You can use a chemical cleaner in a spray bottle, or make your own cleaning solution. To make your own, mix half warm water, half vinegar. Spray down the outside of the dryer, and then wipe it off with the rag. Make sure to clean the lid, too. If gum got stuck to the inside of your dryer,  scrape it with a rubber spatula toss in some rags and then wipe it with your cleaning solution.

steps.headline: Clean the exhaust vent about once a year.
steps.description: Dryer vents can gather lint, which is a fire hazard. If you have a large household and do laundry often, you might have to clean the vent every six months, but if you only do laundry once a week, you can probably do it every other year.If your clothes are taking a really long time to dry, it might be time to clean the vents again.

steps.headline: Unplug your dryer and move it away from the wall.
steps.description: If you have an electric dryer, just unplug the cord. If you have a dryer that runs on natural gas, be very careful as you work on the dryer so that you don’t jostle the fuel hookup. You don’t want any gas to leak out! If you can’t access the dryer vent by pulling the dryer out from the wall, you’ll probably have to hire a professional.

steps.headline: Clean the dryer duct opening with a brush or vacuum hose.
steps.description: Detach the vent hose that connects the dryer to the wall. Depending on your duct, you may have to detach it with a screwdriver. Clean the inside with a vacuum hose, a brush with an extendable wand, or a vacuum cleaner-brush. Wipe away any remaining pieces of lint with a damp rag. Clean as far back in the duct as you can. You can buy a special dryer-cleaning brush, or just use a toilet brush.

steps.headline: Brush out the inside of the vent hose.
steps.description: Start by removing the lint by hand, and use a brush or vacuum to get out any lint that remains. Be gentle as you clean, so that you don’t damage the hose. If there’s an obstruction in the middle of the vent hose, you can carefully scrape it out with a brush and the vacuum out the part you scraped. Try not to clean with anything sharp, because you don’t want to puncture the hose.

steps.headline: Vacuum or brush remaining debris from the outside vent.
steps.description: The outside vent is often outside your home. Remove the plate that covers the outside vent (you might have to use a screwdriver to remove it.) If the outside vent has hinges or flaps, wipe them off with a damp rag. Sometimes rats or squirrels will build nests in dryer vents. Wear gloves and scoop out the nest.

steps.headline: Sweep lint up from behind and around the dryer.
steps.description: Before you shove the dryer back up against the wall, you should take the opportunity to clean behind the dryer with a broom and dustpan or vacuum. Your duct cleaning might have spewed a lot of lint onto the floor that you’ll want to clean up. Make sure to reattach everything once you’re done.
